summary: This is an email chain from March 2020 among FBI and SDNY personnel discussing the organization and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails focus on difficulties in tracking which documents came from which devices seized from Epstein's New York mansion and Virgin Islands residence, and the need for a coordinated meeting and spreadsheet to manage the evidence.

persons.name: SSA FBI New York
persons.context: The sender of the top email, providing an opinion on what SDNY prosecutors are looking for regarding the Epstein search warrant evidence.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: A forensic examiner with the NY Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) who is coordinating the technical review of seized devices and communicating about network issues and evidence status.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The author of a detailed email outlining the challenges in managing the massive volume of seized digital evidence from Epstein's properties and requesting a systematic tracking method.

connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Communicating via email chain about the status and coordination of Epstein evidence review and transfer to SDNY prosecutors.

connections.person1: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: The prosecutor is requesting information and coordination from the forensic examiner regarding the organization and transfer of seized digital evidence.

events.title: Prosecutor requests evidence tracking system
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney emails the team expressing confusion over a new hard drive containing Epstein materials, unsure what is new versus previously received, and requests a systematic spreadsheet to track all seized devices and data transfers.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Forensic examiner provides evidence status update
events.description: The NY CART Coordinator provides an update on the evidence review, noting network issues, that Windows items and loose media from the NY search have been handed over, and that work continues on Apple items and devices from the Virgin Islands.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

events.title: SDNY requests meeting to discuss evidence confusion
events.description: Email chain shows SDNY prosecutors are pressing for a meeting because they are having trouble figuring out what documents came from which seized devices and need to understand the scope of evidence received and pending.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

locations: California (mentioned as travel location for case team)
keyFacts: The document reveals the massive scale of digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties: over 40 devices with storage and 60+ CDs from the New York mansion, and more than 25 devices including servers from the Virgin Islands.
Prosecutors were struggling to organize the evidence, having received a hard drive with over a million documents and folders without clear labeling to indicate which device they originated from.
A key issue was differentiating between newly provided evidence and materials that had been previously received and uploaded, highlighting potential organizational challenges in the investigation.
The FBI was involved in an initial screen of pictures from CDs and devices for child pornography (CP), with an indication the answer was negative, but prosecutors still needed copies for review.

The correspondence shows active coordination and some frustration among law enforcement and prosecutors in March 2020 regarding the management of the Epstein evidence, well after Epstein's death in August 2019.
